B000002KET|4.0|2 -- \\"A National Acrobat\\" what amazes me about this song is how it seems to melt and ooze over you yet careen, rock, glide, chug and pull through.  This is clearly evident when you hear A National Acrobat. It's singularly the quintessential Black Sabbath acid-tab dropping favorite of mine. It says so much, and has such a timeless, deep and dark (secret) quality to it. Though, for a moment, it does break into a happy hip-swaying swagger... I think this was meant to give you the ride through Heaven and Hell like the concept/artwork has encapsulated for you. This song takes on many moods, i have to label it as the standout cut next to \\"who are you\\" and \\"fluff\\".     1 -- \\"Sabbath, Bloody Sabbath\\" keeping in the iconic Sab Sound, is kind of, dare i say over-worked? It's by all means an instant Sabbath classic, but i think it attempts to do what early Sabbath did without such the same impact. In all honesty i feel it was meant to help fans of albums 1-4 make the leap toward this album, and a lot never did whence the song ended.     3 -- \\"Fluff\\" is the most essential acoustic/instrumental Sabbath song of the 70s era. It's pure magic, melancholy, and more. It's Fluff for crying out loud! It'll possibly bring you to tears in the middle of an acid trip, so be careful. This is a very personal album that, fortunately for us, was made public and therefore, unfortunately, has its moment of filler.    4 -- \\"Sabra Cadabra\\", which picks up the pace in swinging carefree move-on-through-with-your-hip-first vibe. It's cool, i like the breakdown of it more in the middle though. Reminds me of parts in Technical Ecstacy before getting back to a swinging groove but this time in a little better way. You can hear the sweat of Sabbath coming through on this song so i give them much credit for it, though it's not what you'd typically call a Sabbath song. It works well enough for me, but there are better gems on this album.    5 -- \\"Killing Yourself To Live\\" starts in much of that same middle of the road vibe, not dark, not too happy... but quickly it takes a dark turn. Now this song, i think, is more of an atavism to that Old Sabbath sound. Whats nice about it though is that it also has an airy/echoey/mystic vibe that Led Zeppelin later embraced, however, done in a very doomy Sabbath way (evident in the chorus). Ozzy's vocals are great and Iommi features with a wonderful solo. The song crescendos up to a speedy, kind of groovin but very hard rocking finish. An all in all great Sabbath song.     6 -- \\"Who Are You\\" marks an groundbreaking moment for Sabbath. It's dark like their early work but Iommi is not responsible. If you're like me you'll still appreciate this track for all its \\"bells and whistles\\". At the heart of this song is a very creepy, mind-bendingly trippy Sabbath song. It's meant to be overly \\"other-wordly\\" and i think it executes the mood perfectly. It's quite a ride, and it belongs with the best of any Sabbath work.    7 -- \\"Looking For Today\\" chugs its way into the mix, and though i like the way it begins, it takes too much of a St. Vitus vibe to it. The hand-clap is annoying and even one part makes me laugh because Ozzy has to sympathize with the listener in the song's message but he sounds a bit purposefully whiney and condescending to me. Makes me laugh, but he does pull it together and tries to genuinely deliver the message when he says \\"when was the last time you cried?\\".    8 -- \\"Spiral Architect\\", Finally. Aside National Acrobat, easily the most grown up and ostensibly wisdom-filled song. It's supposed to be poetic, maybe it's a little pretentious but it has the sound. The warm evoking vibe that does indeed sound graduated. So maybe where national acrobat excells in everyway as the albums best song this song probably wraps up the disc in much of the same way. It starts with a lovely acoustic piece, that could have set the groundwork for an even better song, but it still went in a direction not entirely bad itself. It's chock full ofgood feelings and peaceful tidings. Iommi axe-work ties it together with the orchestration. At times it has been a favorite of mine, but it depends on the mood. Probably not for the narrow minded Sabbath fans on any day.     Kind of weird review for me, because i felt the album deserved to be listened to while reviewed. Take \\"A National Acrobat\\", \\"Fluff\\", \\"Killing Yourself to Live\\", \\"Who are You\\", and \\"Sabbath, Bloody Sabbath\\"... and you have an awesome head-smashing, hardcore sabbath EP. Throw in \\"Spiral Architect\\" for good measure, and then you pepper it with \\"Sabra Cadabra\\" and \\"Looking For Today\\" for time, packaging, and the balance of \\"Heaven and Hell\\" and you have an essential Sabbath release. ------ More cohesive than Volume 4 and maybe less polished than Sabotage, this is right where it belongs, as a great progressive concept piece. You need it because you won't hear songs like this anywhere, i really believe that. And most of I all i think its absolutely necessary to experience it. The songs just have a quality about them that you know the average listener just hasn't been exposed to. It's that dark mystique about it that makes it sacred in your collection.
B000ETQRCM|5.0|Pearl Jam had been fading fast ever since the \\"Yield\\" album.  I remember the 1st Pearl Jam song I EVER disliked came from \\"Binaural\\", and with \\"Riot Act\\", I disliked nearly half the album.  I didn't know what to expect with the self-titled \\"Pearl Jam\\" album, but I was hoping for some sort of a miracle comeback.  Jackpot!  That's exactly what I (we) got.<br /><br />When I first heard the single \\"World Wide Suicide\\", I was skeptical.  Pearl Jam has never been the best at selecting the first single to an album (\\"Who You Are\\", \\"Nothing as it Seems\\"), so I held out some hope.  WWS was a decent song, but no great shakes.  I purchased the album, and upon listening, I was glad my first impression was incorrect.  The album is an absolute masterpiece, from beginning to end.  It's undoubtedly Pearl Jam's finest work since \\"Vs.\\".<br /><br />Stand out songs on the album are, \\"Unemployable\\", \\"Gone\\", and the epic 7+ min masterpiece \\"Inside Job\\", which is unlike anything Pearl Jam has ever done.  It has a cosmic, almost trippy feel to it, and is damn near flawless.  Another song on the album which is unlike PJ has ever done is \\"Parachutes\\", which sounds like a Beatles song.  It's a hit or miss song, which I just so happen to love.<br /><br />Eddie lyrics are as brilliant as ever, and I really came to appreciate \\"World Wide Suicide\\" after I learned the lyrics to the song.  Puts the entire thing in a new light when you're reading the words along with the song.<br /><br />All in all, terrific album, and certainly the best work Pearl Jam has done since the early to mid 1990's.  While this album might not yield many radio hits, it's muscial brilliance in almost every regard.  Pearl Jam has totally redeemed themselves, and I'm looking forward to future material.

B000002GVO|5.0|This album was absolutely huge in 1976 and 1977 and still is today. Hotel California;according to Eagles drummer/vocalist Don Henley was a concept album about the dark side and dangers of the life style of money,sex,and drugs that singers and actors were living in Los Angeles/Hollywood at that time. Many of the songs on this album center around this theme;especially,Life In The Fast Lane,Hotel California,The Last Resort,and Victim Of Love. The addition of Joe Walsh replacing Bernie Leadon was a big improvement for the Eagles. Joe gave them a harder edged sound on this album, and The Long Run which followed in 1979. This was also the last album for bassist Randy Meisner as an Eagles member,before he went solo a year later.Most of the songs on this album have become rock classics and are still played on a regular basis on radio today. The music is a good mix of rockers and mellow songs. Definately,one of the biggest album released in the 1970's.

B000EULJLU|4.0|TOOL is a band that has a huge following and they are a loyal lot. I like TOOL for their atmospheric music and their interesting look at life. The lyrics are very though provoking, but in the end don't mean that much. This band has certainly developed it's own niche in the rock world. It's vision and sonically correct tunes are a worth while listen. However, they are not a drive your car to music style of band. What I mean by that is they are a well thought out story telling band. They are not a kick ass metal outfit with hooks and grooves a plenty. You need to sit in your living room to listen to this stuff to get the most out of it. It does not suite the party atmosphere like most metal head banging stuff does. It's mood music and nothing more. Lots of quite stuff that just kind of rolls along for endless periods of time it seems. Again, TOOL does not lend itself to fist pumping hell raising metal.<br /><br />This cd starts out rather well with well crafted tunes and then gets gentler as it gets further into it. The mix is excellent as all instruments are well defined and the lyrics are indeed thought provoking, but again it's just a cd people not the meaning of life.<br /><br />Overall it's a good offering and well worth the price. I just wish they'd add a little more umph from time to time as those slow passages take forever to get through at times.

0553801503|3.0|The most inventive, intriguing, literate, and engrossing adult fantasy to be written in thirty years, has, unfortunately, hit a rather large road bump with this, the fourth volume. As I don't follow Martin's web site I was not aware that this volume only presents half of the main characters of the first three, leaving out some of the most interesting and loved ones, their portion of this time period relegated to the fifth volume, whenever it will be published. This alone is not that much of a problem; Martin's tapestry is so large that there is plenty of story to be told even within the remaining subset.<br /><br />The real trouble is, he doesn't tell that story for the first five hundred pages! Instead, we are treated to seemingly endless descriptions of heraldry; new viewpoint characters whose stories are definitely peripheral to the original story arc - and this is in a story that already has so many characters that it takes sixty pages of appendix just to list them, definitely posing problems for the poor reader trying to keep track of them all; and way too much scheming and talking rather than action. Very possibly a good half of this work could have been cut without losing any of the important story details, and the net result would have been a much stronger work, better paced, where anticipation of impending action could have been sustained until things actually start to happen, which is about the last one hundred pages of this.<br /><br />That last hundred pages do a fair amount to redeem this volume, where things finally coalesce into definite story lines, and the complex interweave of characters, each with their own desires and schemes to get what they want, which was the overriding trait of the first three volumes, becomes evident again. Jamie at least starts to become an interesting person; Cersie, the person everyone loves to hate, looks like she may have boxed herself into a corner; Sansa, it appears, will be forced out of her safe cocoon and back into being a player in the game of thrones; Arya has, perhaps, the most interesting change in life style and circumstances.<br /><br />If the fifth volume can maintain the pace and interesting events of the last one hundred pages of this work, the full story will be back on track as one of the best fantasies, ever. However, if it too gets bogged down in too much unnecessary detail and non-happenings, I think it will spell the end to this series, and volume six won't be purchased by me at least.<br /><br />Edited 06/12/2011:<br /><br />I just concluded re-reading all four volumes back-to-back. Doing so keeps everything (and everybody) fresh in your mind, and it helped considerably with this volume. Much more of the details seem to have relevance; and at the same time, having seen the long lists of lords and heraldic devices in the prior volumes, made it easier to just skim this material here. I still believe that much of verbiage of this book could have been safely eliminated, and I hope he has made this type of adjustment in the final book, which is finally going to be published on July 12 - a much longer wait than I ever thought would happen. But given my current re-read experience, I'd up my rating a half-star for this volume.<br /><br />--- Reviewed by Patrick Shepherd (hyperpat)r in the game of thrones; Arya has, perhaps, the most interesting change in life style and circumstances.       If the fifth volume can maintain the pace and interesting events of the last one hundred pages of this work, the full story will be back on track as one of the best fantasies, ever. However, if it too gets bogged down in too much unnecessary detail and non-happenings, I think it will spell the end to this series, and volume six won't be purchased by me at least.    Edited 06/12/2011:    I just concluded re-reading all four volumes back-to-back. Doing so keeps everything (and everybody) fresh in your mind, and it helped considerably with this volume. Much more of the details seem to have relevance; and at the same time, having seen the long lists of lords and heraldic devices in the prior volumes, made it easier to just skim this material here. I still believe that much of verbiage of this book could have been safely eliminated, and I hope he has made this type of adjustment in the final book, which is finally going to be published on July 12 - a much longer wait than I ever thought would happen. But given my current re-read experience, I'd up my rating a half-star for this volume.      --- Reviewed by Patrick Shepherd (hyperpat)

That being said, this movie takes extreme dives off that concept. And then there's the abuses the girlfriends of the boys face when the other biker gangs seek revenge. Then the loyalty of the gang kicks in to protect their fellow member's girlfriends.     But the loyalty doesn't last. Kaneda's best friend, Tetsuo is tested on by scientists after being captured by the police for a shoot out. Then Tetsuo is dragged into a series of experiments that melt together his bizzare dreams and reality. And the other patients of the experiments try to kill Tetsuo, only letting loose the worst inside Tetsuo, the jealousy of the strengths of his best friend, Kaneda. Tetsuo acquires a deadly power to blast beams from his hands and body to blow up the whole city, and what's worse, is Tetsuo seeks to strike not only the whole city, but namely, Kaneda.    Akira is one of the first anime films to be released, and master director, Katsuhiro Otomo, who is right at the top with Miyazaki, spins a master tale of friendship and the tests of loyalty. B000DWMN2S|4.0|Yes, I must admit I liked this movie very much, even though I was supposed NOT to like it, after friends had set me up against it with the old, stale phrase: \\"oh, the book was so MUCH BETTER than the film.\\"  Well, different.<br />This point may not be popular, but I really liked the slow sections when the characters were driving around the beautiful Ukraine. In this movie language becomes almost a separate character, just like Eastern European love for \\"Amerika\\" does.  The mix of the old and the new Ukraine is juicy - it makes me want to go there (again).<br />The movie is an energetic leap into the present, complex, \\"globalized\\" Ukrainian-Jewish-half-and-half-and-who-knows-who-is-who-at-the-end  relationships sixty years after the Second World War. It's hard to leap with your feet cemented in the heavy ground of the war and the Holocaust, so the courage and creativity needs to be appreciated.  The young people in the movie are doing their own thing (and going for it), while the last survivors are still alive, watching, making their last (strong) points, fading away...  I think this movie is very important not just as a movie (that is entertainment, to put it crudely) but also on some other level. Risking to sound new-age, I'd say that there's something healing about it.<br />Illuminating?<br />While watching,  I was surprised how few scenes from the shtetl were included.  I thought it was a  big loss, since the shtetl scenes were such a strong and beautiful part of the novel.  Now, on the next day, I think that the movie was just fine as it was. Even the difficult ending was handled well.  Again, I would call it an energetic (and colorful) leap, even though the plot trickles down slowly, there are periods of silence, and driving around Ukrainian dirt roads in a Trabant takes time.
0743454529|1.0|I am a guardian ad litem so this book appealed to me.  That being said, I can't imagine why she wrote about a legal topic when she clearly knows nothing about it.  Her depictions of the lawyers, including the guardian ad litem, as well as court procedure were utterly unbelievable.  The relationship between the Guardian ad litem and Anna's attorney was completely unethical and no lawyer I know of would have engaged in such a travesty without at least letting the other parties and the judge know of the circumstance.  They probably wouldn't be disbarred but they would certainly be risking serious discipline by the bar.  Given that a child was a party, there is no way the judge would have allowed those lawyers to represent her.  At the least, another guardian ad litem would have been appointed.  The mother was referred to as \\"opposing counsel\\" but a lawyer REPRESENTS the client  - the mother didn't REPRESENT the defendant - she WAS the defendant!!  That was simply annoying.  And her representing the husband was  just brain dead material, especially since she clearly didn't talk to him and they had conflicts of interest.  That sort of behavior could get her disbarred.  Calling the guardian ad litem as a witness was ridiculous.  She could give her opinion but not under oath like a witness.  The lawyer being able to get Jesse on probation with one hearing (and no parents around) was in the realm of never land.  Like I said, did Picoult do no legal reserach at all??  And what sort of fantasy would allow the father to take a 13 year old on a fire run???  There was so much wrong with that scenario, legally and other wise, that I don't know where to start.  I don't know enough about the medical aspects to know if that was realistic, but the legal part was wrong 99.9999999 percent of the time.  Quite irritating and something that any lawyer could have corrected if asked.  The legal errors were glaring and saturated the novel. <br /> <br />The ending was just as bad as others have described.  All in all, the most disappointing book I've read in years.

B000A0GP0Y|3.0|The 1974 prison movie is remade AGAIN. The first remake was the 2001 film called `Mean Machine' staring soccer player-turned-actor Vinnie Jones, and now here comes another `The Longest Yard' with Adam Sandler. Both remakes are reasonably amusing, with the original story kept basically intact, plus the reasonable supporting cast, but I still don't know why the four film companies Columbia/Paramount/MTV/Happy Madison had to remake this film now. <br /> <br />Adam Sandler plays the role of ex-NFL player Paul Crewe, who is sent to the jail in Texas after being arrested for `stealing' his girl friend's car and his reckless driving. The warden of the prison Hazen (James Cromwell) asks - or orders - Crowe to organize a football team for the inmates. The warden's idea is, the inmates' team must be so horrible that the guards' semi-professional football team can beat them easily, feeling happy and more confident.  <br /> <br />But you know, the inmates refuse to be losers. After enlisting a help from `Caretaker' (Chris Rock) and Coach Nate Scarborough (Burt Reynolds), Paul Crowe's team named `Mean Machine' get stronger than he had expected. <br /> <br />The director is Peter Segal, whose approach to the material is alarmingly silly at times (inmates' cheerleaders, for example), and as a result the tone of the film is at best very uneven. William Fichtner appears as sadistic prison guard, but his violence is soon forgotten in the following slapstick scenes with supports like Bob Sapp. All in all, the actors supply funny moments and the sports stunts are convincing. Chris Rock and Burt Reynolds are good, if not great, and the brief cameos from Cloris Leachman and Rob Schneider provide amusing scenes, but Sandler is least interesting, far cry from '50 First Date.' <br /> <br />The overlong remake has little to offer except several funny scenes and amusing cameos. In the final chapter the film delivers the goods, but you have to go through the long road to reach that.
6300182282|1.0|I may have once considered this movie to be somehow romantic, like so many other reviewers.  But, that would have been during my single days or during the years of marriage that I thought were happy and stable.  However, after having my world turned upside down by infidelity this movie just serves as a disturbing reminder of the weak emotional nature of so many people who lack the discipline to be true to the fidelity they vowed on the alter.  Now I have to wonder if total reconsiliation is really possible or if people predisposed to this behavior are destined to seek happiness outside of marriage at any cost.  I was starting to believe that couples who survive infidelity can have stonger, happier relationships than they ever experienced with each other before the affair but this movie casts doubt on the cheaters - can they ever really be content with their spouses?  It's a sad reflection on the human condition.  Yes, bitter sweet indeed.
0893860220|5.0|I AM THAT takes the reader beyond the words and the mind into Understanding. This is a remarkable book in that it communicates the REALITY beyond the mere words. Sri Nisargadatta hails from the Navnath Sampradaya lineage of gurus. What makes this lineage so unique and dynamic is the simple method of transmission they employ via the instrument of the mind through Understanding or the recognition of Self. Another way to look at it, is the mind which is the illusory root of ego and separation, is actually used to undo or vanquish itself as a thorn is used to unembed another thorn to use the analogy. The illusion of mind when turned inward or introverted dissolves itself through the Power of Pure Intention and Awareness. This IS Understanding! What makes this Book so Powerful? The Grace of the Guru and the Power of Truth! Together through Compassion/Love and Wisdom, they have the Power to liberate the \\"seeker\\". The Truth that Maharaj transmits through the Grace of His Guru, Sri Siddharameshwar is sublime and subtle. If the aspirant's mind is sufficiently ripe and subtle through meditation practices etc., then these Teachings can facilitate the Final Understanding of REALITY: that there is indeed no/thing or no/body to realize; that Realization is our Natural State, already existing as who we are and ultimately the only REALITY that truly IS. Maharaj's teaching is nisarga yoga or revealing to the \\"seeker\\" one's own innate \\"Natural State\\". Since REALITY is all that truly exists beyond duality and the illusion of the mind, then we are already THAT! Simply our awareness has not been sufficiently purified of concepts, ignorance and conditioning to allow us to merge into Pure Awareness Itself. Enter this Book.Maharaj's Teachings are based on the precepts of Advaita Vedanta and the practice of cultivating Self Awareness through Self inquiry and abiding in the Awareness of I AM. An introverted mind leads to recognition and realization of the Supreme Self or Parabrahman, wheras, the extroverted mind leads to perception of an illusory world revolving around the concept of a \\"doer\\". Once this concept dissolves into nothingness, Nothing remains beyond the REALITY of Self or Parabrahman. Maharaj teaches the \\"Way of the Bird\\" as taught by His Guru, in contrast to the \\"Way of the Ant\\" as taught by most teachers emphasizing years and years of arduous meditation, diets and techniques. As the Bird flies effortlessly from tree to tree plucking the ripe fruits of Understanding so the \\"seeker\\" realizes the Self through this Understanding of REALITY in contrast to the Ant who must climb to the top of the tree to simply taste the fruit and who often perishes in the process. Once the Final Understanding is attained, Self is Realized. The illusion of a separate \\"I\\" and concept of \\"doer\\" effortlessly falls away revealing the Supreme REALITY. Pure Awareness of Awareness. Emptiness abiding in Emptiness. Prior to reading this book, there appeared to be a \\"reader\\" but somehow during the course of reading this Book, through the Grace of Guru and transmission of Understanding, the \\"reader\\" dissolved into a Stateless State of Nothingness, leaving nobody to any longer become \\"realized\\". All that remained was Guru or Self. Such is the Infinite Grace of Guru. To dissolve into the Final REALITY is what this Book is about. And Beyond...OM Namah Shivaya!the extroverted mind leads to perception of an illusory world revolving around the concept of a \\"doer\\". Once this concept dissolves into nothingness, Nothing remains beyond the REALITY of Self or Parabrahman. Maharaj teaches the \\"Way of the Bird\\" as taught by His Guru, in contrast to the \\"Way of the Ant\\" as taught by most teachers emphasizing years and years of arduous meditation, diets and techniques. As the Bird flies effortlessly from tree to tree plucking the ripe fruits of Understanding so the \\"seeker\\" realizes the Self through this Understanding of REALITY in contrast to the Ant who must climb to the top of the tree to simply taste the fruit and who often perishes in the process. Once the Final Understanding is attained, Self is Realized. The illusion of a separate \\"I\\" and concept of \\"doer\\" effortlessly falls away revealing the Supreme REALITY. Pure Awareness of Awareness. Emptiness abiding in Emptiness. Prior to reading this book, there appeared to be a \\"reader\\" but somehow during the course of reading this Book, through the Grace of Guru and transmission of Understanding, the \\"reader\\" dissolved into a Stateless State of Nothingness, leaving nobody to any longer become \\"realized\\". All that remained was Guru or Self. Such is the Infinite Grace of Guru. To dissolve into the Final REALITY is what this Book is about. And Beyond...OM Namah Shivaya!

B00005JOWR|4.0|Big tobacco is of course an old, broad and very deserving target, but the real bullseyes of the satire in Thank You For Smoking are the people in those institutions -- mainly Washington pols, Hollywood and the media -- that assert with a straight face that they are serving the public interest instead of, as Nick Naylor (an excellent Aaron Eckhardt) is happy to admit, paying the mortgage.  Watching that skewering -- which is aided and abetted by the fine performances of Rob Lowe, William H. Macy, and Katie Holmes -- provides most of the fun in Thank You.  It's also amusing that the only remotely human and appealing characters in the movie, aside from Nick and his son, are Nick's fellow Merchants of Death and Robert Duvall as the tobacco company mogul.  The movie goes badly wrong just once, when Nick is kidnapped by anti-smoking vigilantes who almost kill him by covering his body with nicotine patches and make him momentarily an object of sympathy.  Otherwise, Thank You For Smoking is quick on its feet, bright, and often very funny.

B000EULJLU|2.0|On May 12th:<br />As a loyal fan of Tool myself, I bought this CD on backorder so that I can get it delivered to my doorsteps the day it is released. The packaging blows your mind away. Maynard is competing with Trent Reznor of Nine Inch Nails to be crowned the High Pope of Rock n' Roll. Imagine my disappointment after the first listen - and no, it does not grow on you after several times of listening to it. If it does grow on you, you should have a doctor check you for some kind of malignant cancer on your head. The first time of listening is enough to reveal which songs you will hate from that point on. I liked Vicarious and The Pot but they cannot be compared to the greats like Aenema, Eulogy, H, Prisonse*, and of course, Lateralus. Many Tool favorites I will not list here. But this album is very spiritual and will only aggravate the true Tool fans. To say the least, Maynard has decided to retain his softness from A Perfect Circle and give the fans who will not leave Tool a shove to that side. Like most people, I resent being forced fed something I didn't like to begin with. As an artist, Maynard needs to express himself and they will come in many forms. Unfortunately, his increasing spirituality does destroy the soul of Tool and makes 10,000 Days sound like a wannabe Enya. There, I said it. The guitars are wonderful. The drums and bass are undeniably Tool. But Maynard's style is shot. He even skips his trademark hi-low style of singing but it does re-surface from time to time on different songs of 10,000 days to make us mourn for Tool's lost soul. I hope the band makes a public announcement that 10,000 days was created b/c Maynard's voice was recovering from laryngitis. The album sure has enough shi**y filler sounds to cover-up to some great problem within the band. I was suspicious when I first learned the band was doing some heavy promoting for 10,000 Days when they never did it before for other releases. Maybe Maynard really did find Jes** (research this story on your own). I'm praying to G** this is a fake album and that Maynard hasn't lost his mind. Here's a break down of the songs:<br /><br />Vicarious - you've heard it on the radio. Yes, this is good but far from great. Maynard accuses us for being TV junkies and cowards. No problem, Adam Jones' guitar makes up for the shortfalls and forgives Maynard's pettiness.<br /><br />Jambi - nice but very personal to Maynard. Message is unclear but some of his talented lyric writing can be sifted through to break our hearts for what Tool was before this album. Yeah, I'm dimming my eyes and holding on for one more day to Tool as well...<br /><br />Wings for Marie (pt I) - here comes the first of many wannabe Enyas. This one commits the unholy act of using the rock n' roll guitar to put you to sleep. Tool sounds like Santana on this song while breaking out a riff in order to kill you quietly as you see the band's soul go under.<br /><br />10,000 Days (Wings pt II) - unbelievably boring. Tool has never disappointed on the Title track but this album has broken the golden rule. I dare anyone to stay awake listening to this song. First time you hear it - yawn. Second time - yawn to tears. Third - deep slumber.<br /><br />The Pot - this song breaks my heart. Dying struggle as Tool appears to make a comeback on the album. The topic is funny and for days you can still hear echoes of \\"You must've been highhh...\\" singing in your head. Maynard's singing this? No longer the trademark hi-low singing but music made by rock musicians who wannabe great. His singing style makes a comeback and the guitar is properly restored towards the end of the song but it will not last long. Just like a dying man trying to breathe his last breath.<br /><br />Lipan Conjuring - this is Tool?!!! Navajo singing style - this intermission song is best used to conjure rain in the dry desert.<br /><br />Lost Keys (Blame Hoffman) - Tool's trademark weirdness is stylized by their dialogue tracks. This is a dialogue track. But whereas other dialogue tracks on the previous Tool albums help to entertain, this one again breaks my heart at seeing such a great band go down. A reminder of what could have been.<br /><br />Rosetta Stoned - the guitar follows and constantly reminds you of Tool. The background riff is from Schism, can Maynard revive this song to make it climax like Eulogy at the end? \\"Godd***, should've known, don't know, can't remember what he said...\\"<br /><br />Intension - this song puts you in a trance. Kind of like Reflections from Lateralus but nowhere near as catchy.<br /><br />Right in Two - climax is too short and towards the very end. Song sounded better with the guitars and drums before the meaningless lyrics. But what would Tool be w/o great messages (think of \\"Do unto others what has been done to me, yeah...\\" or \\"We are eternal all this pain is but an illusion...\\")? I just wanna scream \\"Come back to us Maynard!\\"<br /><br />Viginti Tres - could've been a part of greatness like Ions belonged to Aenema or Triad on Lateralus but nothing. A whimpering of an ending to a wussy album.<br /><br />This album seals the victory to Trent Reznor as High Pope of Rock n' Roll. If Maynard beats up Marilyn Manson, we can forgive him for 10,000 Days - but only if there's blood...<br /><br />Update May 15th - 3.5 stars:<br /><br />I hate to say it but : Godd***, the album really does grow on you. I have to adjust this review to tell you a little more about the album after several listening sessions. I had been tearing open the packaging of the case to see if there could possibly be a hidden secret CD compartment somewhere because I really did not like 10,000 Days. As many of you know, there isn't a secret CD and like other loyal Tool fans, I had to give the CD another listen. Well, here's the secret: you need to catch Maynard's lyrics. Some have called the lyrics cryptic and impossible to decipher. As a loyal Tool fan, you learn to understand his strange way of singing and figure out his words. Here's what I think the content of the songs are but keep in mind my ideas are yet to be verified by the Tool Army:<br /><br />1. Vicarious - still the same song about us being TV junkies and cowards. Adam Jones is still excellent on the guitar. Later on in the song, Maynard tells us the \\"universe is hostile, so impersonal, as its always been\\". Vicarious gets cute after a few listens, even though it sounds good the first time you hear it (and I don't like cute).<br /><br />2. Jambi - very much like Tool and Maynard. Still unclear if he is directing this song at us or about someone personal to him. \\"If I could, I would wish it all away/ If I knew I would lose you one more day...\\" ??? The high point in this song are the lines: \\"breathed(?) like the fire dust to dawn, begged like a hooker all night long/ enchanted the devil with my song, and got what I wanted all along\\" -  which says Maynard is aware of his songwriting talents. Frankly, I am too but you might disagree after this album. At the end of Jambi, Maynard says \\"Breathe in...and survive another day, and season/ silently just take your poison/ Silently and run my way...\\" ? What does this all mean? I think Maynard is trying to inspire us much like he did on Lateralus. He has a way of moving you without becoming sappy about it. I still don't know why he would write a song like that - maybe he's trying to become a parent to us? (And if so, Maynard, if you're reading this, go easy on the idea) Jambi is still a very catchy song and I really like it.<br /><br />3 & 4. Wings for Marie I & II - songs are about religion and its ability to deceive both its followers and preachers. It's pretty deep and Maynard adds a twist into the lyrics to say that we have more than one alternative to decide on while the preachers do not. He tells the listener we have choices and that eventually we'll make the right one: \\"10,000 days and the fire's been burning long enough, you're going home...\\" I'm not going to type upthe lyrics here but listen to the song close enough and you'll be able to pick up his meaning. I have to say the mixing on this track could use some work - it's still too slow. But Maynard gets some points for the subject material.<br /><br />5. The Pot - this song is probably the first to stick in your head. He decries the hypocrisy of both drug users and their accusers. This song is the most difficult to decrypt because it's hard to understand what Maynard is saying and what his position is. So just sing along if you don't know and contemplate about his words if you do.<br /><br />6. Lipan Conjuring - native Indian chant song. Call it the spiritual voice you hear when you're high (right after Track 5).<br /><br />7. Lost Keys (Blame Hofmann) - dialogue between a nurse and a doctor. Nurse has found a patient w/ some problems she doesn't understand. End of Track 7, doctor is speaking to the patient and urging patient to talk to him, \\"Tell me everything.\\" Prelude to Track 8 - Rosetta Stoned. Same guitar notes playing in the background as Track 8.<br /><br />8. Rosetta Stoned - this song is trippy but very fun. It's about an alien abduction and the patient is telling the doctor to write down everything he is telling him. He's describing his abduction, how scared he is, and how ET told him he was the \\"chosen one\\" but he can't remember what they told him. It's important because it will make him a hero but he's so scared that, in retrospect, he should've asked them for mercy. \\"Strapped down, feet cold, and eyes red... Godd***, should've begged.\\" Hilarious song - raging good music with a hilarious story. You get the storyline from the beginning when he's just speaking rapidly about parachuting down Area 51 and seeing some lights. Funny and catchy and my most favorite song on the CD.<br /><br />9. Intention - song about the cruelty of humanity. \\"Pure is as we begin/ Here we have a stone/ Throw this thing at strangers/ Swear to crush his bones...\\" And again \\"Spark becomes aflame/ Flame becomes a fire/ Spark this flame at strangers/ Take what we desire...\\" Not a gripping message but you got to give Maynard credit for trying...<br /><br />10. Right in Two - another song about the cruelty of humanity. This time Maynard plays heavily with religious imagery: \\"Why did father give humans free will?/ Now they're all confused\\" and then he calls humanity silly monkeys that fight each other over every little thing. I'm touched that Maynard can be so sentimental but this song is too touch-feely for me. I like him more when he's cold-hearted and with wicked ideas (Prisonsex, Stinkfist, Aenema, Ticks & Leeches). This song doesn't really help me grow, it annoys me.<br /><br />11. Groaning song is very creepy and ends the album to make you restless. I'll sleep fine but you might have a problem.<br /><br />I will continue to like Tool after this album and I still think Maynard should consider my suggestion for him to beat up Marilyn Manson. But I think Tool and Maynard are heading for retirement. They've just lost their edge after so many years of being in the limelight and their softer side is touching, however, it's no longer Tool.<br /><br />Thanks for reading!

B0000033P2|5.0|This 1972 release is a fantastic group effort and is a little bit softer around the edges than the comparatively aggressive and edgy Tarkus album (1971).  The album opens with the lengthy two-part The Endless Enigma suite that features a full-blown fugue sandwiched in the middle.  Greg Lake (bass and vocals) contributes a pleasant ballad with From the Beginning that provides a nice contrast with the complexity of the Endless Enigma suite.  Continuing the tradition of including lighter pieces on albums, which ELP started on Tarkus, there is the Sheriff.  This is actually a good song and features some excellent drumming by Carl and great Hammond organ work by Keith. With the opening of the instrumental rendition of Aaron Copland's Hoedown, the pace picks up a bit and features some searing Hammond organ work and trumpet-like fanfares on the mini-moog by Keith and great drumming by Carl.<br /><br />The three remaining tracks include the long-ish Trilogy (8'53\\"), the shorter piece Living Sin (3'12\\"), and the synth-heavy closing track Abbadon's Bolero (8'07\\").  I guess it's worth noting that the piece Living Sin was ELP's token song to the topic of sex - this is pretty rare indeed, not only for ELP, but for prog in general.  In fact, Greg adopts an uncharacteristically low, growling and husky tone for the piece - just to emphasize the subject matter.<br /><br />Rhino did just an OK job remastering this album and I have to admit that it is substandard when compared with the remastered Yes albums.<br /><br />All in all, this is a superb group effort by ELP and is a fine album of progressive rock. Trilogy is highly recommended along with Emerson, Lake, and Palmer (1970), Tarkus (1971), and their crowning achievement Brain Salad Surgery (1973).
B000EMGAOY|4.0|I've read the negative reviews on here and they all say the same thing: This isn't like BloodSugarSexMagic! I too was taken aback because I read a pre-release review that said that this album was back to the old-style of the Chili Peppers and was their best album since BSSM. That reviewer must not have listened to BSSM before because this album is nothing like it. <br /> <br />Stadium Arcadium is an incredible album and would've been a perfect follow-up to Californication (instead of the awful \\"By The Way\\" - which was easily their worst record since Frusciante joined). SA shows the Peppers growing and evolving into a mature rock band. While this doesn't get funky like BSSM, it's hardly a snoozer. The musicianship has never been better and it sounds like they've figured out what worked so well on Californication and what didn't work on By The Way. <br /> <br />I've given the album 4 out of five for two reasons: (1) I would've liked to have seen a few more of the funk/rock/rap tunes that they built their career on, and (2) while this is a GREAT double-album, it may have worked better as a single. It's almost as though there is WAY to much good material for a single album but not quite enough to justify the double. <br /> <br />This is definately a classic album and deserves to be mentioned right up there with the Chili Peppers other classics: Mothers Milk, BloodSugarSexMagic, and Californication.

1582403589|4.0|What happens when the world we know is gone, possibly forever, and every day is a constant struggle for survival? Would we still fall in love, write poetry, decorate things, take time to read a book, or make plans for the future? How would a world gone mad affect the contemporary family unit or a religious organization? These are the types of things looked at in detail in \\"Days Gone Bye\\", the first volume in the Walking Dead series of graphic novels. Most contemporary media dealing with the subject of the apocalypse focuses on what occurs immediately before or after the great event that ends civilization (in this case, an infestation of zombies taking over the planet). The Walking Dead, however, is more of a long term project, focusing mostly on characterization. While there is certainly both action and horror present, these things are a vehicle to display the characters and how they react to the situations they find themselves in.<br /><br />The artwork is very good, and a welcome change in a genre that is mostly saturated with Japanese Anime style art. The main artist, Toni Moore, has gotten facial expression down to a science. It is readily apparent when any given character is sad, or joyful, or full of fear. An absolutely priceless facial expression is on the first page, in which an enraged (and probably drunk) escaped convict is screaming about never going back to prison. He has a very \\"I'm a crazy country bumpkin, don't mess with me or I'll chainsaw you\\" look about him. My one gripe is really about all graphic novels in general, although it definitely applies here. The use of emphasis on words is always completely off in comics. Either too many words, or the completely wrong words, are bolded (indicating emphasis on that word), which throws off the flow of the dialog.<br /><br />The story revolves around Rick, a police officer who awakens in a hospital after being shot on duty. The world has somehow become zombie infested, and he's all alone. This chapter of the saga is about Rick's search for his family, and his decisions on what to do next once he does actually find other living people. Several subplots pop up, mostly having to do with the backgrounds of the various minor characters, and hopefully they are explored further later on in the series, as these are all characters you can imagine actually being people you know and care about.<br /><br />If the first installment is any indication, this series is just going to keep getting better. Highly recommended to fans of zombie mayhem and standard drama fare.ut Rick's search for his family, and his decisions on what to do next once he does actually find other living people. Several subplots pop up, mostly having to do with the backgrounds of the various minor characters, and hopefully they are explored further later on in the series, as these are all characters you can imagine actually being people you know and care about.     If the first installment is any indication, this series is just going to keep getting better. Highly recommended to fans of zombie mayhem and standard drama fare.

B000E1155E|5.0|Ive just spent some time looking over the reviews and I disagree with what I have read, although I am not suprised. This is one of the best british albums that has been released in years. Unfortunately for American listeners you have the disadvantage of not understanding the irony within the lyrics or the many british references that Alex Turner incorporates into his songs. He is a Yorkshire Lad and sings about the local pimp and 'Novas' and 'burberry' caps all of which fall onto deaf ears for an American audience but as a british listener are relevant and hillarious. B000003TAL|5.0|Before I say anything about the album, I just want to make clear that I don't know anything about Sonic Youth's early work (pre-EVOL era) so I can't make comparisons to it and this album. <br />At Allmusic.com, they recommended Sonic Youth's album \\"Sister\\" so I purchased it and was very impressed when I played it.  They also said \\"Daydream Nation\\" was even better so I purchased it as well.  I must say that I have never heard anything quite like this album before or since then.  The first thing I notice as I played the opening track \\"Teenage Riot\\" is that it had alternative and Indie Rock written all over it.  Kim Gordon, the group's bassist, began singing indecipherable lyrics to a soft yet somewhat abrasive electric guitar texure.  The pace then picked up and Moore entered in, singing lyrics that one could just barely make out under the greatly distorted guitars.  There was really not much of a melody but instead a surrealistic landscape of jagged guitars and the groups trademark feedback techniques.   <br /> <br />The second track \\"Silver Rocket\\" is really where the lion is let lose, however.  A very punkish attack with Moore once again yelling out inaudible lyrics and then an incredibly abrasive aftermath of atonal white noise that mimics the effects of bombs going off.  As the album continues through its tracks, the atmoshpere changes but the theme remains the same.  Often you're just recovering from the barrage of one song when your thrown into the fury of another.  There are many suprises along the way such as the avant-garde track \\"Providence\\" which cotains a rare use of a piano set in the background of a constant and almost unbearable rumbling noise. <br /> <br />The horrifying sounds continue throughout the album until it all comes crashing to a halt on the last track.  There's not much melody and no pop hooks whatsoever.  Instead everything relies on texture and creating a mood and feel to the music.  This is not an easy album to last through a whole uninterrupted listen.  You may find yourself listening to this like you would read a book; listening to it up to a certain point, stopping, and then picking up from where you left off.  This group was clearly inspired by the Velvet Underground and, like the Velvet Underground, they mostly had just a cult following, though this album helped them gain some critical respect and exposure to the mainstream.   <br /> <br />Summary: <br />This is a critical piece of Indie Rock and Alternative Undergroud music.  It may take you a few listens to get used to it (and don't expect to make it through the whole thing on the first listen) but you will be greatly rewarded in the end.

B000087DRK|5.0|I know that's a pretty massive claim, but I can more than back it up.  Take everything that should be great about an album, then look at this one.  A good album should musically be good.  AD has some of the best music you will ever hear.  Not this 3 chord bs, nor the hubris of Phish.  At the same time, the music itself is part of the brilliance.  Solos (insanely fast ones at that) dot the album.  They're literally everywhere.  Yet, at the same time, that's the point.  The solos are meant to be humorous, as they go where they don't belong.  Think of a more talented version of Spinal Tap.  At the same time though, they have enough originality and pop sensibilities that they never fall into self parody, even though you couldn't tell looking at a lyric sheet, which brings us to point number two.  Lyrics.  They fit into the music, adding to it.  When you hear the epic intro to Age of Pamparius, you expect the lyrics to come and be some life-affirming apocalyptic grand poetry, but instead they're about pizza.  Once again, Spinal Tap.  But once again, they work, and have enough to stand on their own.  They're funny, but at the same time not stupid, and fit into the overall mood of the album.  As far as influence goes, just look into the tribute CD.  Everything from techno to black metal.  As rock and roll, it's what rock and roll was always supposed to be: fun and dangerous.  Think of Alice Cooper fronting the Ramones, produced by the Village people and you'll get a good idea of what this album is about.  Way better than Sgt. pepper's.

B000EULJLU|5.0|There are so many reviews complaining about this album not being \\"heavy\\" or not being different enough. Even more so, they complain about no climax to the music.  Yet, have you listened to it with the intent of hearing the music and lyrics as a whole?  Tool has always been heading more into the realms of the subconscious and trying to bring it forward; if you listen to this album with the intention of picking it apart stylistically, you won't ever find the depth of it. <br /> <br />Granted, I am sure they prefer that their albums have a high sales rate, but I don't believe that the band is really looking for uber popularity.  Most of their lyrics talk about expansion of the mind and trying to \\"unhook\\" from being a mindless, soulless blank face that is no different than all of the others.  If you stop patting yourself on the back and just _listen_ to what Maynard is saying, it isn't gibberish. There are clues to the paths they follow hidden in Maynard's riddles. You just have to be determined to track down the sources from which he is bringing his message. This means doing a bit of research... <br /> <br />If you aren't the curious sort and you don't want to understand what Maynard is trying to say, just sit back and let the music roll over you. You'll find in yourself a new place anyway.  I know it sounds like a bunch of spiritualistic, metaphysical hogwash but music has transported people into trances since the first drummers started drumming.  The layers of music that they weave aren't just for show, but to disorient you from everything that you are surrounded by and to help guide you away... <br /> <br />Stop trying to pick apart everything and analyze it to death, sit back and listen for the sake of the album. Don't ruin the magic of Tool's albums by trying to categorize, name, and summarize.  That is the beauty of their music, they are going beyond all of that. <br /> <br />I'm done. Thanks. Bye.
0930289528|5.0|This is an early example of the graphic novel, and it is really amazing how quickly the form of the graphic novel matured. There are some important points in this story that most politicians or Hollywood filmmakers still have not grasped: a fascist government does not appear overnight, and it most often enjoy great public support - at least in the beginning - since it brings order; we don't need masked heroes, they are just a mirror of ourselves; the collapse of a totalitarian government leads to a new chaos, which can easliy lead to a new totalitarian government; the rulers do not see themselves as evil - they think they perform a public service, and servants of the government are not necessarily evil, they might just see the alternative as worse. <br />The novel has a quite complex structure, with plenty of flashbacks, a sudden break in the narrative about two-thirds into the story, and a an end that is not so much an end as a the beginning of a new story.  <br />The story is more believable because of its strucure: we get to undersdtand the society the protagonist live in, and how it began. The characters are really three-dimensional, except for some deliberately shallow ones. The pain, madness and suffering of the masked fighter are very carefully developed. <br />I have not yet seen the film, but the directors appear to have tried to change the story a bit to keep the message intact, but more applicable to our own age and times.

B000F5GO0A|5.0|Largely the work of an ambitious youngster named Zach Condon, Gulag Orkestar is an indie rock album filtered through the mind of a teenager who dropped out of high school to travel across Europe and soak in as much culture and music as possible. The result is something that sounds a bit like the Microphones crossed with Neutral Milk Hotel. It might be the only rock album you hear that doesn't contain any guitars, and it conveys an emotional and worldly power of the likes I've not heard in some time.<br /><br />  Largely inspired by Balkan folk music, the album moves through mournful ballads and more upbeat tracks (that sound more like the work of a 10-plus member ensemble) with ease, layering horns, stringed instruments, ukeleles, mandolins, glockenspiel, drum, organs, piano, and other percussion under the soulful vocals of Condon himself, who has a similar range and style as Andrew Bird. The disc opens with the album-titled track of \\"The Gulag Orkestar,\\" and after some warbling horns and cascading piano, the track turns into a shuffling march that finds Condon soaring over the top of it all with his rich croon.<br /><br />  The album really hits stride with the gorgeous \\"Bandenburg,\\" which finds deft mandolins playing out over heaving drums and percussion as accordions wheeze and the track builds gracefully with delightful horn sections and layered vocals. \\"Postcards From Italy\\" follows, and it may very well be the best track on the disc, moving along with a playful opening section that mixes shuffling mandolin, piano and horns before shifting halfway through to a more delicate (and reflective) section that completely tugs at the heartstrings before bursting into a celebratory ending that's absolutely stunning.<br /><br />  The second half of the album finds Condon taking a few more chances, and amazingly he pulls things off just about every time. \\"Scenic World\\" uses a programmed casio-beat that sounds straight out of Magnetic Fields, but layers horns and accordion over the top for something completely unique while \\"After The Curtain\\" takes the non-traditional instrumentation and runs it through some filters, giving the track a slight electronic tinge without making it ever feel out of place. It seems like every year there's an album that comes completely out of nowhere and really stuns me, and this year that title is easily held by Beirut with Gulag Orkestar. An outstanding debut album, and easily one of my favorite releases of the year so far.<br /><br />(from almost cool music reviews)for something completely unique while \\"After The Curtain\\" takes the non-traditional instrumentation and runs it through some filters, giving the track a slight electronic tinge without making it ever feel out of place. It seems like every year there's an album that comes completely out of nowhere and really stuns me, and this year that title is easily held by Beirut with Gulag Orkestar. An outstanding debut album, and easily one of my favorite releases of the year so far.    (from almost cool music reviews)
B000002LRX|5.0|It's been said many times before, but this album truly is a classic.  It's creative, original, bizarre, unpretentious, and utterly perfect.  I love every FNM album (well, all the Patton ones, anyway), but in my opinion, this one stands out above them all.  In fact, I'd say that this is probably the best album Patton's ever done, in all his myriad projects (even if it's not the most artistically daring).  Here, everything just really came together, and the result is remarkable.<br /><br />While not as cutthroat in its diversity as Mr. Bungle, this album still covers a lot of musical ground.  You've got dark, nightmarish metal, like \\"Malpractice\\" and \\"Jizzlobber\\", funk-tinged tracks like \\"Crack Hitler\\" and \\"Land of Sunshine\\", raprock like \\"Kindergarden\\" and \\"Midlife Crisis\\", smooth, lounge-esque balladry like \\"Everything's Ruined\\", and \\"RV\\", which I can only describe as something like a deranged clone of Johnny Cash.  Then you have songs like \\"Be Aggressive\\", \\"A Small Victory\\", and the instrumental \\"Midnight Cowboy\\", which seem to forge styles all their own.<br /><br />This album is just plain fantastic.  The keyboards complement the music in a very special way, and Mike Patton proves to be one of the great vocalists of our time (plus, he heavily influenced other great singers, like Devin Townsend, Daniel Gildenlow, and many others).<br /><br />Simply put, you just can't be without this album. 0385732554|5.0|Lois Lowry is one of those unique authors who has won the John Newbery Medal for children's literature twice. Once for the first book in this trilogy and once for a book about the Holocaust called Number the Stars. (Just as an aside only one other author has ever done that Madeleine L'Engle who I would also recommend highly.) I would begin by recommending any of her books; they are all worth the time and the effort.  This trilogy is set in a post apocalyptic world. The first two books each focus on different community's who have recovered from the devastation differently, both have strengths and both have weaknesses. And a young boy must heal them both and the land if either is to survive.<br /><br />The Giver<br /><br />Lois Lowry<br /><br />Laurel-Leaf Books<br /><br />ISBN:0440219078<br /><br />Jonas is a young boy who lives in a community with a lot of technology and many rules about it. He has only seen an airplane twice for planes were not suppose to over fly villages, it was against the rules. Children of the same age are raised together and each December they move up a grade, when the reach the age of twelve they are selected for occupational training Jonas in talking to his friend states about selections: \\"Jonas Shrugged. It didn't worry him, how could someone not fit in? The Community was so meticulously ordered, the choices so carefully made.\\" However all the other Twelve's were assigned and Jonas was skipped then at the end of the ceremony it was announced that he had been selected he was chosen to become the `receiver of memory.' He was to learn all the history and story of the people and become an advisor to the council that ruled the village. It only happened every so many generations and only 1 keeper of memories was installed in each village. Jonas and his family take in an infant who is not maturing and growing quickly enough. The child is given a year extension, when the child is marked to me replaced (abandoned and killed). Jonas takes the child and runs away. Through the winter Jonas knows he will not make it and pours all the memories he has learnt into the child. But can he save the child? What will happen to him and his community? Jonas thought his world was perfect, that the elders had everything under control, that there would never be war again. But also a world without choices. Till he is given the knowledge of the past the choice to save a child or let it die?<br /><br />Gathering Blue<br /><br />Lois Lowry<br /><br />Laurel-Leaf Books<br /><br />ISBN:0440229499<br /><br />Kira, is an orphan and she has a twisted leg, she lives in a village with very little technology and one that casts aside those who do not contribute. The weak, injured, and helpless are abandoned. However things are starting to turn around for Kira, she has been spared by the all powerful Council of Guardians, for she has a gift she is a weaver and can die cloths in ways no other in the community can. As an artisan she is installed in the palatial Council Edifice and spends the whole year working her trade, her primary task is to care for the Robe of Remembrance that tell's the story of this community. But with her privilege comes expectations that she will do the council biddings. She befriends a young boy and his ragged dog, Matty `The Fiercest of the Fierce'. Matt tells Kira about another village where people are not cast aside, where they share their food. Matt brings her a gift the color blue, and a blind man that is her father. She is torn between staying and leaving the life she knows, and the truths she can find out what will happen.<br /><br />Messenger<br /><br />Lois Lowry<br /><br />Thomas Allen & Son<br /><br />ISBN:0618404414<br /><br />Matt has returned he is with Kira's father and living in the new community from beyond yonder. This village is guided by love and compassion, and guided by the `Leader' a seer arrived in this village one winter night many years ago on a sleigh with an older boy who did not survive the journey. The Seer can see the future and can often see for people what might be for his people. Matty is almost at the age where he will be named, he is hoping to be named `Messenger' for he takes message both in the village and to other villages which many can not do. But things are changing, the village is becoming hostile, starting to turn people away and the woods are becoming ferial and people are dieing. Can the Leader save the village, can the world be healed, what will happen to Kira, her father and Matty?<br /><br />These three books will challenge you, after reading The Giver the first time I was overwhelmed and it haunted me for a long time. I went back and have reread it many many times. All three books raise questions about community, love, friendship, and care for other people. They also show dark paths that we as a people can go down, and how it can devastate all around us when we make the wrong choices for the wrong reasons.future and can often see for people what might be for his people. Matty is almost at the age where he will be named, he is hoping to be named `Messenger' for he takes message both in the village and to other villages which many can not do. But things are changing, the village is becoming hostile, starting to turn people away and the woods are becoming ferial and people are dieing. Can the Leader save the village, can the world be healed, what will happen to Kira, her father and Matty? <br /> <br />These three books will challenge you, after reading The Giver the first time I was overwhelmed and it haunted me for a long time. I went back and have reread it many many times. All three books raise questions about community, love, friendship, and care for other people. They also show dark paths that we as a people can go down, and how it can devastate all around us when we make the wrong choices for the wrong reasons.
B000EMGAOY|5.0|I am a long time fan of the chili peppers but I don't think that biases my review of this product. <br />Stadium arcadium runs the musical spectrum and is one of the deepest albums in the last 30 years.  There is plenty of funk for the old school fans but also a fusion of melody that was lacking in many of the blood sugar sex magic tracks.  The title track, stadium arcadium, is so beautiful that it could have walked off of Pink Floyd's \\"Dark side of the moon.\\"  Other tracks, my personal favorites \\"torture me\\" and \\"hard to concentrate\\" display a range and depth far beyond most bands.  I challenge anyone to play both CDs through and not lose themselves in the music.  Arcadium is a testament to the RHCP's ability to continually create excellent music and it may be there best effort to date!
0007111827|5.0|Lois Lowry is one of those unique authors who has won the John Newbery Medal for children's literature twice. Once for the first book in this trilogy and once for a book about the Holocaust called Number the Stars. (Just as an aside only one other author has ever done that Madeleine L'Engle who I would also recommend highly.) I would begin by recommending any of her books; they are all worth the time and the effort.  This trilogy is set in a post apocalyptic world. The first two books each focus on different community's who have recovered from the devastation differently, both have strengths and both have weaknesses. And a young boy must heal them both and the land if either is to survive.<br /><br />The Giver<br /><br />Lois Lowry<br /><br />Laurel-Leaf Books<br /><br />ISBN:0440219078<br /><br />Jonas is a young boy who lives in a community with a lot of technology and many rules about it. He has only seen an airplane twice for planes were not suppose to over fly villages, it was against the rules. Children of the same age are raised together and each December they move up a grade, when the reach the age of twelve they are selected for occupational training Jonas in talking to his friend states about selections: \\"Jonas Shrugged. It didn't worry him, how could someone not fit in? The Community was so meticulously ordered, the choices so carefully made.\\" However all the other Twelve's were assigned and Jonas was skipped then at the end of the ceremony it was announced that he had been selected he was chosen to become the `receiver of memory.' He was to learn all the history and story of the people and become an advisor to the council that ruled the village. It only happened every so many generations and only 1 keeper of memories was installed in each village. Jonas and his family take in an infant who is not maturing and growing quickly enough. The child is given a year extension, when the child is marked to me replaced (abandoned and killed). Jonas takes the child and runs away. Through the winter Jonas knows he will not make it and pours all the memories he has learnt into the child. But can he save the child? What will happen to him and his community? Jonas thought his world was perfect, that the elders had everything under control, that there would never be war again. But also a world without choices. Till he is given the knowledge of the past the choice to save a child or let it die?<br /><br />Gathering Blue<br /><br />Lois Lowry<br /><br />Laurel-Leaf Books<br /><br />ISBN:0440229499<br /><br />Kira, is an orphan and she has a twisted leg, she lives in a village with very little technology and one that casts aside those who do not contribute. The weak, injured, and helpless are abandoned. However things are starting to turn around for Kira, she has been spared by the all powerful Council of Guardians, for she has a gift she is a weaver and can die cloths in ways no other in the community can. As an artisan she is installed in the palatial Council Edifice and spends the whole year working her trade, her primary task is to care for the Robe of Remembrance that tell's the story of this community. But with her privilege comes expectations that she will do the council biddings. She befriends a young boy and his ragged dog, Matty `The Fiercest of the Fierce'. Matt tells Kira about another village where people are not cast aside, where they share their food. Matt brings her a gift the color blue, and a blind man that is her father. She is torn between staying and leaving the life she knows, and the truths she can find out what will happen.<br /><br />Messenger<br /><br />Lois Lowry<br /><br />Thomas Allen & Son<br /><br />ISBN:0618404414<br /><br />Matt has returned he is with Kira's father and living in the new community from beyond yonder. This village is guided by love and compassion, and guided by the `Leader' a seer arrived in this village one winter night many years ago on a sleigh with an older boy who did not survive the journey. The Seer can see the future and can often see for people what might be for his people. Matty is almost at the age where he will be named, he is hoping to be named `Messenger' for he takes message both in the village and to other villages which many can not do. But things are changing, the village is becoming hostile, starting to turn people away and the woods are becoming ferial and people are dieing. Can the Leader save the village, can the world be healed, what will happen to Kira, her father and Matty?<br /><br />These three books will challenge you, after reading The Giver the first time I was overwhelmed and it haunted me for a long time. I went back and have reread it many many times. All three books raise questions about community, love, friendship, and care for other people. They also show dark paths that we as a people can go down, and how it can devastate all around us when we make the wrong choices for the wrong reasons.future and can often see for people what might be for his people. B000EHSVOG|5.0|Ok, Obviously The Towering Inferno is a bit dated and does show its age.  Several of the top cast members (Steve McQueen, William Holden, Fred Astaire) have passed away, and we won't even get into O.J. Simpson, but this is still a great movie.  Many have probably forgotten just how big this movie was some 32 years ago.  This was a mega-blockbuster, earning well over $100 million which is quite a sum today, let alone in 1974.  Back then Hollywood was in love with the disaster film with movies such as Poseidon Adventure, Earthquake, and Airport, all having big name casts.  It's a clich? but its true...they just don't make them like this anymore.<br /><br />The Tower is a new state of the art mega-skyscraper built in L.A. by wealthy James Duncan (Holden).  Paul Newman was the building's architect Doug Roberts.  A huge gala black-tie event is going on to celebrate the opening of the new building on its top level.  A fire breaks out on one of the lower floors and Roberts suggests to Duncan that the party be stopped or at least moved to one of the lower floors for safely.  Duncan is incredulous and tells him that there is nothing to worry about.  Well we soon find out just how wrong he is!  It turns out that Duncan's son-in-law Roger (Richard Simmons) oversaw many of the details and he went against Robert's specifications by using substandard wiring to save money.  Soon the building is engulfed by flames and the party-goers find themselves trapped on the top floor where no ladders are tall enough to reach them.<br /><br />Steve McQueen, in one of his final roles, is Fire Chief O' Halloran who is charged with not only containing the fire, but somehow rescuing those people who are trapped and is probably the strongest character in the film.  Simpson actually makes a pretty good accounting of himself playing a heroic security guard.  Of course knowing what has happened to him makes watching him onscreen a bit uncomfortable.  Other co-stars include Susan Blakely and Robert Vaughn.<br /><br />Of course the real star was the special effects led by legendary effects pioneer Douglas Trumball who worked on such films as 2001: A Space Odyssey, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and Blade Runner.  Without the benefit of modern day CGI, the special effects team truly convinced the viewer of the harrowing ordeal that these people faced.  Even the rescue attempts where they transport people in the basket is quite thrilling.<br /><br />The DVD is packed with special features including several short featurettes, deleted scenes, commentary by film historian F.X. Feeney, and more.  Definitely more goodies than you would expect to find on a film that is over 30 years old.  It looks and sounds great as well.  Still packs a punch!<br /><br />Reviewed by Tim Jansonbert Vaughn. <br /> <br />Of course the real star was the special effects led by legendary effects pioneer Douglas Trumball who worked on such films as 2001: A Space Odyssey, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, and Blade Runner.  Without the benefit of modern day CGI, the special effects team truly convinced the viewer of the harrowing ordeal that these people faced.  Even the rescue attempts where they transport people in the basket is quite thrilling.   <br /> <br />The DVD is packed with special features including several short featurettes, deleted scenes, commentary by film historian F.X. Feeney, and more.  Definitely more goodies than you would expect to find on a film that is over 30 years old.  It looks and sounds great as well.  Still packs a punch! <br /> <br />Reviewed by Tim Janson <br />

B000A3XY9Q|5.0|Okay here's the poo! I'm 23 and as previously stated collect movies(DVD mostly) and this is a classic.If you want to know what it's about scroll down and there's a hundred reviews explaining it. That being said this is a classic!!. Horror,comedy,and Bruce Campbell what more should be said, but seriously this has some of the most twistedly funny scenes I've ever seen plus it's modern history this is one of the top ten cult classics ever,If you don't believe me about it being twisted check out dead linda dancing or the moose/hand scenes it's beautiful gore/comedy at it's artistic finest.I am NOT some dumb punk kid,I'm educated and a public servant (City Employee) so don't write my views off.For as cheap as this is especially on amazon used or new,it SHOULD be purchased.This movie does not dissapoint(although a little demented!!).Thanks for your time,Now buy this sucker and JOIN US! B000078DOH|4.0|Before they were international superstars known for their soothing, mellow and soulful ballads, the Red Hot Chili Peppers were four poverty-stricken L.A punks making some of the funkiest music known to man. In the spirit of P-Funk recordings from the 70s, Freaky Styley is laden with springy bass lines, funkdafied guitar, and edgy, uneven drum grooves. Far from accessible, Freaky Styley is nonetheless an interesting, unique, and extremely original white-boy funk album. <br /> <br />The most intriguing prescence on the album would most certainly be guitarist Hillel Slovak, whose funky guitar dominates almost any track, lifting all of them to new heights. Tracks such as \\"Hollywood\\" and \\"Jungle Man\\" are guitar heavy, with super-charged funk-laden riffs that are as musically complex and interesting as much of John Frusciante's work. His noodling will no doubt be respected by listeners of all ages and backgrounds, even if it's not necessarily their kind of music. The virtuoso bassist Flea has some interesting pieces here as well, but don't be expecting any of his genius that comes through on Mother's Milk or BloodSugarSexMagik. He was surely one of the most talented bassists of the eighties, but he had yet to come into his own as a songwriter, as some of the basslines are repetitive and are consistently dominated by the outstanding guitar; Slovak and Flea are both extremely talented, but don't have the chemistry that the Frusciante-Flea team display. <br /> <br />Anthony Kiedis also had yet to become the lead singer he is today, his voice has very little range on this album, and his lyrics are seriously undeveloped. Tracks like \\"Catholic School Girls Rule\\" are fun, but will leave the listener wanting more after five songs in a row witht he same lyrical content. His charismatic and confident voice however, makes up for many of its shortcomings, and he definitely connects with the rest of the band. Cliff Martinez gives very strong work here as well, easily rivaling anythingcurrent drummer Chad Smith has done over the years. <br /> <br />If you've heard Californication and By the Way and are looking for some of the funkier Chili Peppers, I would suggest starting with BloodSugarSexMagik. If you enjoy tracks on that such as \\"Mellowship Slinky in B major\\" and \\"Sir Psycho Sexy,\\" Freaky Styley would be a great second purchase. Drenched in L.A cool, it's a unique, funky and outright weird experience you won't soon forget. <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br /> <br />
B0006M4SO6|5.0|I don't understand why some people don't like this recording, oh well... everybody have their own taste. :-) <br /> <br />But for me this is a great journey that we must have a special time to listen to this CD without any interruption. <br /> <br />After the introduction, you will hear the main theme and they keep moving on from improvitation to improvitation to other theme... etc... etc... with interesting chords progression or beat progression. At the end of the song, you can imagine and feel like you're really going up to sky and I love the 'imagination' when listen to this song. <br /> <br />Pat, you're the man. Thanks for the unforgettable journey.

When I picked up the second issue of The Chronicles of Narnia, the renowned classic \\"The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe\\" I was interested to see if it lived up to the constant praise it received. <br /> <br />Again I insist, this book is very enjoyable-- it is not, in my mind, worthy of being called a classic. Narnia is a refreshing world that is beautifully described... when Lewis takes the time TO describe it, that is. I definitely do recommend this book, but I also warn the readers not to expect a classic like Harry Potter or Lord of the Rings. <br /> <br />While I don't enjoy Lord of the Rings as much as Harry Potter, I see why it is a classic, from the beautifully descriptive writing to the twisting plot, but \\"The Lion, The Witch, and The Wardrobe\\" falls short of this. One last time, I will restate that while this book doesn't live up to the hype, it is ENJOYABLE and makes the reader smile often. <br /> <br />PS: It is a great story to be read aloud!! <br /> <br />6/10 <br />
